title: (x) Dwell magazine nameplate - (similar to) Trade Gothic {Stephen}
content: does anyone know the typeface for dwell's logo? thanks!
author: fc

comments.content:
what about link.....

[http://www.dwellmag.com/](http://web.archive.org/web/20141009103101/http:/www.dwellmag.com/ "http://www.dwellmag.com/")
I think [it](http://web.archive.org/web/20141009103101/http:/www.magazines.com/magcom/covers/0/06/330/0063304.jpg) is completely constructed, not a typeface.

[Trade Gothic](http://web.archive.org/web/20141009103101/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=catalog.fontdetail&displayfontid=LH.108133.0.7&attributes.sampleSize=48&sampleText=dwell&sampleSize=48) isn't a bad start.
do you think it's constructed from news gothic, but not quite...
yeah. i guess they took out the lower strokes and made the W kind of funky.
Interesting. The 'w' could have been made by merging two 'v's together. Nice idea.

When thinking Trade and News Gothic, don't forget Tobias Frere-Jones' recent interpretation: [Benton](http://web.archive.org/web/20141009103101/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=verity.search&searchstr=benton).
i think you're right, trade gothic looks the closest and indeed, the "w" looks like two v overlapping. good point.
So maybe it's not called Dwell but actually Dvvell with some overzealous kerning action?
Chesh! Where've you been!?
I guess they want their own proprietary logo that's different than readily available types!
Precis, fc. This is why most logos are custom.

Oh, ick — I loathe pedantry. But here, if anywhere, we ought to be accurate about publishing industry terminology.

A magazine’s masthead is not its nameplate (the place where the logo appears). A masthead is the list of editorial and publishing staff.

--Kathleen

Looks like the two definitions are acceptable:

From WordNet (r) 2.0 :

**masthead**

1. a listing printed in all issues of a newspaper or magazine (usually on the editorial page) that gives the name of the publication and the names of the editorial staff, etc. [syn: flag]
2. the title of a newspaper or magazine; usually printed on the front page and on the editorial page

Kathleen is absolutely correct. (BTW -- hi Kathleen, long time, no talk)

Masthead has mistakenly been used so often instead of the correct terms of _nameplate_ or _flag_ that it has taken over through common misuse.

Many years ago I worked for two newspaper publishers, _masthead_ ONLY referred to the section that carried the name of the publisher, chief staff and place of publication.

I guess it's the same way that FONT has now become what we called _typeface_.
But maybe it took over because the word is so appropriate for the thing. "Mast" (standard bearer) "head" (top, headline).
i'll agree with norbert and kathleen on this one. when i found this out i was crushed as i was taught at design school that masthead (also called flag) was the correct term.

Well, language is supposed to be a dynamic thing, innit? I've known other instances where through continuous popular misuse certain words or definitions became acceptable and made it into the dictionary. Now that I know I will try to remember and use the correct term, but we'll have to wait and see what the future brings.

_\> Oh, ick — I loathe pedantry._

Heh heh heh. This board is one of the places where pedantry is warranted. We don't mind to be educated. Heck, that's the whole point of this website! ;^)

If we can't be pedantic, I gotta stop posting here. :^D

\> _“Mast” (standard bearer) “head” (top, headline)._

Yes -- as misused by us landlubbers.  
But to mariners, the masthead ( [photo 1](http://web.archive.org/web/20141009103101/http:/modelers.tallshipmodels.com/dianaproject10.htm)) is the topmost section of the mast which bears the rigging. A flag or pennant can be flown from the masthead or flagstaff, a pole extending above the masthead.

So the _masthead_ bears the work, like the staff of a publication.

\> _This board is one of the places where pedantry is warranted._   
Thank heavens! I'm generally considered a bore at cocktail parties.
